Enjoyed in a sam adams perfect pint glass  A: pours a crystal clear light golden color with a large amount of very active carbonation bubbles and a finger of very fine bubbled pure white head which lingers nicely and is slightly creamy in character on its surface, leaves a nice amount of spotty lacing on the glass S: a pretty interesting scent with a nice sweetness like grapes and a nice light malt character like white bread T: begins with a nice clean hop note which is lightly floral and hits on the palate for the first half of the sip, it is then backed out by a nice gentle malt character which lends way to a fresh sweetness like cane sugar which lingers on the palate nicely afterwards M: pretty strong carbonation tingle, then becomes a bit of a fizzy yet creamy character which bubbles its way across the palate before leaving the mouth nicely dry and yet clean O: a nicely hopped and complex lager which dances across the palate with a pleasant character and overall crisp taste, just plain well rounded

I went into Boston Lager expecting a Coor/Budweiser/Miller/Michelob equivalent, but it is in all honesty far beyond that.  I have had Sam Adams Imperial White before, and this resembles a less intense version of that. Noble hops are clearly present in a passive form, and there is a more bold taste over the traditional american style lager.  Head retention and lacing is ideal, the aroma is crisp, the finish is refreshing, and overall, this is absolutely best american lager I've ever had bar none.  I highly recommend this as a permanent upgrade for anybody considering bringing any of the 4 beers mentioned in the opening paragraph to a party. It's just better. No debate about it.

BBE August, 2012. Poured from a 12oz bottle into my Moonlight shaped pint glass.  Brilliantly clear orange peel/amber liquid is topped by a low creamy layer of off-white foam. Light sticky lacing, good retention.  Clean faintly nutty/toasty malt aromatics. Perhaps a very light grassy note from noble hops?  Bready (or rather, toasty) palate entry with layers of malt. Moderate, clean, hay-like bitterness leads into a pleasing rather dry finish.  Light-bodied, zesty mouthfeel.  A very good example of the style. Easy to drink, but it "scales" well for the appreciation of the beer enthusiast as well.

Almost always the best beer available at places that aren't craft beer oriented.  Very nice looking beer, good dark colour, still some transparency.  Smell of hops and slight but of fruit, nice strong taste, with a little bitterness at the end.  A go to beer on many occasions.

Lovely light golden amber with a good sized head and wonderful retention. Nice lacing. Smell carries a nice malt sweetness and good yeasty bread with a lovely spiciness and light leafy hop character. Taste is well balanced with a solid, bready malt core of caramel with a hint of molasses and caramel sweetness. Superbly balanced hop bitterness is an artful combination of florals and spicy but gentle Sazz like notes. Feel is crisp with mildly a carbonated, almost creamy touch. Light enough for sessioning but enough weight to satisfy with one. A great beer in total and one I enjoy again and again. If my drinking consisted of this and a few choice now and thens I would find enough quality, variety, and flavor to be happy.

Ok, so the first time I tried this beer was from a bottle, with which I was not particularly impressed. Had it on draft one night at a local pub and it was miles better...  A: Light amber/copper color, finger and a half fluffy white head, well carbonated, good looking brew.  S: Bready caramel malts, with a light floral/pine, spicy hop aroma.  T: Spicy hops with sweet caramel malts, a bready toasty character also present. Slightly piney and florally, nice mild grassy hop bite, not overly complex but very solid.  M: Crisp, refeshing, light-medium bodied with good amount of prickly carbonation.  O: A tasty beer and always a solid choice when looking for a step up from a macro lager. The epitome of a gateway to craft beer. On tap, this is an exceptional beer imo, bottled version however isn't as good as the tap version

This is by far the best American style lager I have had. Maybe they should change the name to Samuel Adams "Perfect Balance". Balance between malt and hops are amazing and hit at the just the right time, neither being overpowering. Carbonation is spot on as well. This is definitely my year-round go to beer. I like a few other SA beers but it's often hard to beat the original, a true American staple I'm proud to drink!

Poured into a perfect pint. Pours a golden-red with a finger and a half of white head. Smells of toasted malt and spiced hops. Nothing too extreme, but quite pleasant nonetheless. Taste is a smooth balance of light roasted malt, hop spice and lingering bitterness. The mouthfeel is surprisingly full-bodied for a lager of this style. Overall a very sessionable beer and a reliable standby and a great option to introduce a novice to craft beer.

This is a personal favorite that always makes me feel more American when drinking it. It pours a crystal clear, beautiful amber color with a fluffy white twin finger head. The head fades to leave a thin lacing around the glass. It had a malty smell that is hard to detect but easy to taste. The flavor is a mellow malt taste with slight alcohol. As it warms it becomes more complex and the hops are more noticeable. Mouthfeel is a little thin but with nice carbonation. Overall a reliably good beer that walks the line of craft brew and mass appeal. I'd drink it any day.

Look: Clear yellow/gold with a thin white head with heavy lacing  Aroma: Heavy on barley with a hint of hops  Taste: Crisp malted barley with a smooth finish, but a slightly skunked aftertaste  Feel: Crisp start and very light on the tongue  Overall: A decent beer, but nothing special

On tap in a Samuel Adams perfect pint glass. Dark Amber with 2 finger, white foamy head. A good amount of lacing.  Smell of malt sweetness with little spice.  Nice full flavor of malt, just the right spiciness from the hops and crisp finish.  Solid medium mouthfeel from the strong malt backbone, smooth carbonation.  Overall a very solid beer.

We enjoyed the dark golden lager on tap, which was capped with fluffy white head that provided plenty of lacing as we enjoyed the taste. Spicy and earthy hop tones blend into some caramel and toasty malt aromas in the nose. Sweet malty flavors of caramel and a slight breadiness blend wonderfully into some slightly spicy hop flavors, very well balanced. Clean and crisp, Boston Lager features a medium-light body and moderate levels of carbonation. Always a good choice!  Cheers!

12oz bottle served in a SA perfect pint glass.  pours a bright, bell-clear golden amber tone with a little more than a finger of puffy, off-white head; moderate retention and some respectable lacing evident.  nose is primarily of caramel malts followed by some subtle floral/earthy hops. good aroma, though not especially robust. flavor delivers the caramel malt backbone which is accompanied by some background hoppy bitterness and a clean, crisp finish. pretty balanced. a bit unexciting with its lack of complexity, although i'm admittedly not steeped in experience with this style, or lagers in general; perhaps complexity is not a chief selling point. medium bodied/carbed on the palate.  overall a bit underrated i think, what with boston lager being so widely available, but a very solid craft offering that could enjoyably be sessioned.  original review on: 09-09-2010

Just starting out with really trying to taste and enjoy real beers. Thought I'd try one of these, so I poured it into a pilsner.  At first, it had a nice sweet aroma and taste, but as I drank I started to feel more of its bitterness. The aftertaste left somewhat of a sour sensation in my mouth, could've been a bad brew maybe. However, the sour aftertaste was a minimal setback and this beer's sweetness stayed true.  I think it's a good start for starting to drink better beers, and that said, there are plenty of better beers out there.

When reviewing a lager something to keep in mind is the fruity and complex flavors we look for in ales, whether they're IPA's, stouts, american pale ale, browns, ect. should not be present in a lager. Dunkel, helles, doppelbock, pils and schwarz are all lagers and therefore the most prominent feature in taste should be a clean malt profile; the trademark of a good lager. That being said...  Samuel Adam's Boston Lager pours with a decent two finger head (into a Samuel Adam's glass) and has brilliant clarity and substantial amount of carbonation. The color is a lovely amber/medium caramel and has good lacing.  Pretty mild on the nose but does have nice noble hop aroma and a pretty well defined sweet toasted malt aroma as well.  The beer is slightly sweet and has a great malty flavor with a slight toffee finish. A great session beer and it's availability makes it a great alternative to the BMC versions found everywhere. Highly recommended, especially if you know someone that is a novice when it comes to craft/specialty beers.

Poured into a pilsner glass. About time I get to try this, too. It's most definitely an important classic in the craft beer world.  There's a nice little amber color, a fluffy head, and lots of carbonation. Simple and to the point. What wonderfully looking lager that this is.  The smell is delicious and refreshing. A sugary aroma, near tartiness, and filled with crisp cereal grains and tons of orange/citrus fruitiness underneath.  While the flavor is leaning towards the malty, grainy side, there's enough hops in here to hold long term interest for me. The yeasty flavor really clashes well with the clear and clean tasting flavors. While the carbonation can be a bit too much at times, it adds a kick that is fun and noticeable. I wish this were sweeter, but overall this is a nicely balanced beer that's easily a crowd pleaser.  While not my favorite lager (not sweet enough, as said earlier) this is still quite good. Definitely a staple that I wish others would follow in making good quality Euro lagers, and has remained this way for decades.

A- Light amber body with a bone white head. Good lacing.  S- Caramel malt comes through the most with a light hop presence.  T- Similar to how it smells, caramel malt character throughout with some hop presence to balance it out.  M- Crisp, clean, not overly carbonated.  O- Classic lager, well balanced, good beer for anytime.

Served in a Samuel Adams signature pint.  Appearance: A darker gold, thin white head coming off maybe 1/4" off the body.  Smell: Hints of light pine, and floral type of feel when you smell it.  Taste: Robust in flavor and simply complex, light bitterness and feeling of toasted hops.  Mouth: medium to full carbonation, just freaking smooth!  Overall: Pound for pound one of the best beers, I have had it religiously especially when I hit the bar it is the best fail-safe out there. It has everything to offer, Salud!

Pours a nice golden hue with a nice 2finger that laces beautifully. I get a nice earthy maltiness from the nose blended nicely with fresh hops. This has a wonderful medium mouthfeel with nice carbonation that highlights some nice fresh earthy Bavarian hops, deep toasted malts, grain, bread, biscuit, a creaminess near the end that leaves a great malty sweetness in the aftertaste.  A great american brew that is widely available. Less dry than the boston ale, and more hops that seems to blend well.  Cheers!!

Excellent appearence and smell. Taste a little on the bitter side for me. Good to enjoy one before lunch. Clear golden color. Head not formed well on the glass I used for the taste test. I am not really a fan of bitter beers, maybe I have to get accustomed to it before I can rate another bitter beer

Pours a dark amber, with an off-white head leaning towards yellow. Good retention and decent lacing.  Smells of whole grain, roasted malt, bitter herb, and a slight nut aroma.  Taste is hops up front bitter herb and some slight bitter citrus punch. Roasted chewy malt comes next with some caramel notes a nice full body. Finishes dry with a bitter herb bite. An excellent beer. I hadn't had this since I got into craft. Returning to it now, I am surprised how good it still is.

Poured from a 12 oz bottle into a standard pint glass.  A) Amber in color. Clean looking with bubbles heading to the surface. A nice finger of creamy looking head, that settled to a dusting. A bit of lacing too.  S) Malt dominates the nose with that initial whiff. A real pleasing sweetness, followed by light hops producing an aroma that is grassy and slightly floral.  T) Nice malty sweetness, bready, touch of caramel. This has a nice earthy quality. The hops presence blends in very well. Light grass, with a clean finish.  M) A medium body with not as much carbonation as I thought based upon appearance, but it is done right. This beer is both smooth and refreshing. Nothing wrong with the feel of this one.  O) Lagers kind of get overlooked a bit in my opinion. I myself am slightly guilty of this, so it's always a good idea to enjoy a classic craft brew, such as Boston Lager. This is just a really solid beer, super easy to drink, perfect session option.

On tap at an Orlando Airport bar. Served in a shaker pint glass.  Appearance: Clear amber with a white 1/16" thick dense foam (fine bubbles). Plenty of persistent lacing on the glass.  Smell: Not a lot of aroma - bit of crisp grain/mail, with some German type aroma hops thrown in.  Taste: A bit of roasted malt up front and moving quickly into a hop bitterness. Much less malty than I remember.  Mouthfeel: Just south of fizzy - high carbonation. Some thickness underneath the carbonation.  Overall / Drinkability: I wonder....did the bar get this beer diluted? It doesn't seem up to snuff somehow. I seem to remember this beer as maltier when I've had it in the past, but maybe my palate has changed so much I'm tasting this quite differently than I remember. Not sure. I'll have to try it one more time at a place where I know I can rely up on the quality and see if the beer is different yet again. If it's better - this one is getting deleted as again, something isn't quite right or my palate has really changed a lot since the last time I had this beer.

In a pilsener (also had in a pint glass, nothing changed):  A: deep golden amber colored body with a lumpy foamy white head that leaves some of the foamy lacing in rings down the glass  S: fair amount of malts up front with some light caramel and toffee that are very faint  T: malts and caramel come back but are once again pretty faint, gets hoppy as it warms  M: light to medium, excellent choice for a session, no aftertaste, no finish, carbonation is barely felt  O: well this is Sam Adams' flagship, what can I say, I don't speak bad about this one, its good for the style and good for me

A: Poured into a 12oz mug. Appears a nice amber color with an off white head that dissipates rather quickly.  S: Some sweet toasty malt with quite a bit of citrussy, grassy hop character beneath.  T: Similar to the nose, with lots of caramel and toasted malt, with some bready and fruity flavors there as well. Has a pretty intense snap of hoppiness with a lemonny, herbal flavor. Finishes dry.  M: A bit heavy, but the carbonation supports it nicely.  O: I still consider this a very good beer. Nice drinking.

Deep golden amber colour with a thumb sized and bumpy and foamy white head that has good retention.  Lots of malts upfront with a good blend of caramel and toffee that takes a few moments to open up in the glass. It was quite clean but with some grassy hops and a touch of citrus too and a touch of grain right at the end.  Malts and caramel with touches of toffee and a strong, sweet taste. Like the aroma, the flavours took a minute or two until they opened up and became more noticeable. A nice and mild, bitter malt flavour rounds off the flavour.  Light to medium in body and with a good sweet malt flavour. It is a smooth and refreshing beer that goes down quite well.  An excellent beer that was very refreshing and had a great, sweet malt flavour and just the right amount of bitterness in the finish.  1001 Beers Blog: http://abarwithnoname.wordpress.com/1001beers

This is worth it. This is, in my opinion, one of the best session beers that won't break the bank. It smells great and malty, tasting like it smells. I would drink this any day. The color (golden) and body (medium) and head (lingering) are more typical of ales which make this lager a great and interesting beer. Go pick up a 6 pack

12oz bottle poured into a mug  A: Poured with a three finger creamy and foamy slightly off-white head on a fairly aggressive pour. Clear orange/bronze color. Decent amount of carbonation. Lots of lacing on the glass.  S: Spicy hops and sweet bready malts strike a nice balance in the nose.  T: Just like the nose, the taste holds spicy hops and bready malts in a very nice balance. Aftertaste is a bit earthy.  M: Medium/medium-light body. Carbonation is okay. The mouthfeel is the weakness of this beer in my opinion.  O: Boston Lager is a classic for sure. The style is pretty plain, but it's a very nice beer. I'm glad Sam Adams puts it in all their mixed packs because while I enjoy this beer, it isn't something I would buy in a six pack.

12oz bottle from Sams mixed 12, have had multiple times before reviewing. Poured into Sam Adams glass.  A- Translucent golden with a slight reddish hue. Not too much in terms of head, just a thin layer of white head (couple mm) that leaves nice layered lacing.  S- Malts, hops, some caramel, a little bit of barley.  T- Lightly sweet and a little bit bitter. Some caramel, hops, malts, very slightly sweet aftertaste.  M- medium bodied to a tiny bit on the light side, goes down easily, average carbonation.  O- Living in Boston, I've had the Boston Lager quite a few times. It is a decent go to beer that is always in the Sam Adams mixed 12 pack. Nothing amazing, but always a decent session beer.

A: pours a clear light amber into a "Perfect Pint" with a finger of head that hangs around fairly long and leaves some spots on the side.  S: some sweet caramel malt is up front when all of the sudden the light citrus forward hops sneak in and make their presence know subtly.  T: sweet malt, bread/biscuits, apples, oranges and done. In that order just like that. Its simple but almost perfected like a master chef serving up a Mac' and Cheese dish.  MF: lighter body and smooth, steady carbonation keep these going down quite well.  D: overall an extremely well made beer. I think my only problem with it is a problem of mine and comes with the territory. Its simplistic. But its so good and like I said its not the beers fault the trend leans to the over indulged complexity hogs.

A: Pours deep golden with a massive white thick head that slowly sinks into nice lacings.  S: Bready malt, somewhat sweet. Some grassy hops. Quite neat and clean.  T: Bready malt, mild sweetness. Hops is both floral and bitter. Some peppers and some undefined fruityness; perhaps red apples.  M: Aftertaste lingers with a bitter, but more sweet feel. Body is medium and creamy while carbonation is mild.  O: A nice beer, nothing too exciting though.

Had this in the bottle and poured into a pint glass. I have not had this in ages and forgot that this is one of those iconic beers that changed beer to more of a craft. Great color. Good head. Nice balance and mouthfeel. This is still a very solid craft beer.

Drank from the bottle, but took aroma and taste from a third of the bottle poured into a glass tumbler.  Appearance: Deep amber, orange in colour. Thin one finger head that dissipates fairly quickly and does not leave too much lacing. Carbonation is light.  Aroma: First thing to hit me was the chocolatey, toffee like smell, sweet notes, hint of fruit, probably berries. Certainly a 'sticky' sweet chocolate/toffee smell.  Mouthfeel: Mild, not very lively, a bit dry but not like an ale. Pleasant for a lager.  Taste: Woody, smokey tastes at first, with a sweet finish. In this I got a hint of the toffee note in the aroma, and perhaps fruit. Aftertaste lingers for quite a while, the grainy, woody taste and eventually a strong flavour of fruit.  Overall: A fantastically complex lager that is one of my favourites of the style now. Very drinkable, will definitely be picking up more for the fridge.

Maple Syrup In Color With A Creamy Head. (Almost A 2 Finger Head) Medium Lacing. Taste is Slight Citrus And Slight Honey With Prominent Hops, Balanced With Caramel & Malt. Hoppy Aroma Between Sweet & Bitter. Samuel Adams Is Definitely Steps Ahead Of Your Typical American Macro Lager. - A must try for anyone who is entering the world of craft beers or who wants a lager with better taste, scents and mouth feel. This lager is excellent on its own or paired with pork and beef dishes. It's highly drinkable and a great brew in my opinion. Well Done Boston Beer Company!

Deep amber color with an ample white head after the pour. Gives off a decent hop aroma, but nothing spectacular. Flavor begins malty with some hop bitterness increasing in prevalance over the finish. Thin mouthfeel. A well balanced beer, but nothing remarkable.

Maple syrup amber with a small fizzing head of off white froth. Perhaps a finger high with average retention. Leaves spots of lace on the glass.  Honey, maple syrup and a pleasant caramel grain. Saaz hops, earthy and grassy, very pleasant. Slightly acidic and lemony on the nose as well.  Follows the nose with more caramel and honey sweetness in the mild grains. Ends moderately bitter with a slightly grassy and metallic bite. Dries well.  Crisp finish with a bit of muted carbonation for a lager. Medium bodied and very refreshing. Little bit of acidity as it lingers.  Crisp, flavorful, drinkable. The poster child of American craft. Well

22 oz bomber poured into a nonic pint.  A- pours a nice amber/copper color topped with a big tan head, leaves good lacing.  S- lots of caramel and grainy malt, some light grassy hops.  T- loads of malt, caramelly and sweet, some grain and spicy, black peppery and grassy hops, bitterness just provides balance and let's the caramel take over.  M- medium bodied, smooth feel, way drinkable.  O- a classic, its fallen out of my regular beers recently but I'll have to go back to it more often because it's still a great, tasty beer.

Oh how i have yearned for this delicious treat all semester! (I usually have to frequent PBR or Keystone Ice. YUCK!)  OK THEN!  AR: Quite malty. Maple Syrup notes. Sweet hoppiness. I'm a little underwhelmed, but it still smells delicious!  AP: Practically looks like maple syrup. Lovely head retention (about 1.25"). Good lacing.  T: God, it's good. Maple syrup, hops, malty sweetness. Very robust throughout. A little acidic in the end, however nothing is offensive. Very nice drinking. Good with burgers or wings or steak.  MF: I won't lie, i was looking for a little more carbonation, but it suffices. Frothy and creaminess throughout.  O: One of my favorites and something i try to have often. Decently priced. Yeah, there's quite a few better beers, but this one definitely deserves respect.

Poured into a Tulip as I wanted to bring out all the aromas of this beer. Honey colored body with medium carbonation. Smells of strong caramel notes,bready, malty and a hint of orange peel. Strong hints of bisuit tells me this style of lager stands out a bit from the others.Flavor: Malty, hoppy, bready and finishes with a punch in the face of honey . Flavours stuck around on the palate for a nice while before eventually disappearing which made me want to go back for more. Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation which makes this beer very easy drinking and a good session beer at any circumstance. Overall this was a very enjoyable beer. I could see myself drinking this on a cold snowy night here in Colorado or with a greasy hamburger or hotdog. For the price and availability this is an A+ beer.

Ap: Dark, caramel, maple syrup color. Modest head, approximately 1" and it fades away slowly leaving a decent amount of lacing.  Ar: Very malt like aroma. Sweet and mild hops on the note. Very mild and unoffensive. A tasty treat awaits.  Ta: Mild malt flavor. Hops are present but very mild. Very acidic and bitter aftertaste but it is pleasant. Each sip gets better suggesting it improves as it gets warmer. It maintains a nice robust flavor throughout. Mild tones of maple syrup exude themselves.  Mf: Not too heavy but a mildly frothing and creamy texture. Appeals to almost every tastebud on the tongue. The texture is compelling and complete.  Ov: The prototypical craft beer gateway. The price point is acceptable and it invites a novice drinker to explore it. What lies ahead is proof that better options are in store. There are far better choices, but almost everyone should embrace this stepping stone before climbing the entire mountain of exquisite beer selections.  Cheers!

Poured from a 12 oz bottle into a 14 oz "pint" glass. Pours a darker straw color with a small white head that dissipates slowly and leaves great lacing. Smells of malt dominantly and some sweet tones, possibly from hops, but cannot put my finger on it. Tastes of sweet malt with a a little bite of hops, but definitely on the malt heavy side, which is fine for a basic lager, but this one is superiority more flavorful than most American lagers. Carbonation a tad heavy, but not offensively so. Goes down smooth with no bad aftertastes and definitely sessionable. Overall, a very good beer and one of my mainstays when I go to bars with not much selection of on tab beers, as many will have this one.

12 fl oz brown glass bottle served in a pilsner glass, reviewed live:  A - Pours a transparent copper color with 3 fingers of soapy, off-white head. Retention is very good, and the head leaves some lacing as it recedes.  S - Pilsner and crystal malts dominate. Caramel, light spice, and some vaguely earthy and grassy hops notes are present. Clean, but pretty simple.  T - Follows the nose closely, though the hops are definitely more pronounced. It's simple, built and balanced well, and decent quality.  M - Medium bodied, smooth and wet. Not really complimentary of the flavors.  D - It's always been a decent beer for me; one that's drinkable, fair quality, and fairly priced.

I work in Korea and I found a few slightly out of date bottles at my local Home Plus'uh'. I gather it's a mass produced lager from America because it's widely available here in Korea.  A: Light amber. Superb head retention.  T: Lovely hoppy bitterness. Floral and very spicey with lots of boiled honey and citrus, bit of malt. Eerily reminiscent of Oakham Ale's J.H.B., my favourite beer, but lacking dimension, more like a pale immitation. It's still complex, but I'm finding myself willing it to go further. Sweet but not sticky, robust enough to be complemented by a conical pint glass. Really hard to believe it's a lager. Good sustained aftertaste.  O: I was expecting it to taste like Bud or Millers so I was quite taken aback by its hoppiness, exactly the sort of profile I like in a cask ale. Not quite a world class beer, but as far as mass produced lagers go it's the dogs bollocks, very flavoursome. As a default beer this would definitely appeal to British ale drinkers. Would easily rival Guinness. I'll definitely drink more but on the whole, the flavour, although delicious, just doesn't go far enough for me though.

Poured from 22oz bottle into pint mug, sipping it right now.  A- Nice copper color, one finger head that stays a bit, nice lacing left behind, carbonation bubbles.  S- Floral, bread, spice.  T- Hops, toasted malt, little caramel.  M- Medium body, nice hoppy after-taste, smooth going down.  O- First tried this a few years ago, and did not like it...this was back when I knew no beer other than BMC products. I normally get two of these 22oz bottles a couple times a week now. $1.99/bottle, makes a good after dinner treat.

This is my favorite beer when I'm having a steak at Texas Roadhouse in Paducah, KY... Great beer on tap. This review is for the bottle version.  Appearance/Smell -- Not much there. Average at best.  Taste/Mouthfeel -- This is where this beer excels.. An excellent beer. Samuel Adams' flagship beer and my favorite Jim Koch creation.  Overall -- Again, this is a must pairing with steak. Try it and see if you don't agree.  .

Look: very clear orange amber color with good looking lumpy frothy head. Smell: pretty faint spicy hop. Taste: good lager graininess with a good bite of hop spiciness. Lots of grain coming up on the palate. Light bitter aftertaste, faint apple fruitiness. good punchy crispy feel

Reviewed from notes.  Pours out a standard amber color with good clarity and an impressive craggy two fingered white fluffy head which lasts for a minute but leaves behind nice loops of lacing. Has a total aroma spectrum of noble hopping: earthy, spicing, and herbal all represented in approximately equal amounts in both the nose and in the flavor alongside a lovely caramel malt, all with a smooth medium bodied texture that has the right amount of carbonation too keep things lively in the mouth without being overly distracting. One of the staple workhorse lagers on the market, and it is not difficult to see why.

appearance nice looking golden red color  smell better smelling than your average lager, but still not much going on, sweet malt and slight hops  taste tastes like it smells, good for a lager, but not too much going on  mouthfeel just the right amount of carbonation and density, very good for a lager  overall haven't tasted a ton of beers the world over, but this is one of the best lagers I have tasted, getting a decent smell and taste into a lager is a nice accomplishment, good job sam adams

Poured from 12oz bottle to pint glass  A- Pours a golden hue with large pillowy white head that sticks around just for a little bit before heading off to other adventures in Jim Koch's world  S- Quite malty but still clean very slight hops in the background. Smells like the typical lager, not a ton going on but smells nice  T- Hoppier than the smell but thats not saying much. Still get the sweet malty taste you'd expect and it finishes when it leaves your mouth, not a lingerer.  M- Best part about drinking this beer, super smooth with just the right amount of carbonation.  O- Best thing about this beer is if I'm in a shitty bar in the middle of nowhere I can find this on tap and be happy with it.

Defnitely a good beer. Perfect balance between hops and malts. Pours a nice frothy head. Immediately notice hops and finishes with nice malty sweetness. This beer is good for just about any occasion. For sure an American classic without too many peers.

I have had this beer many times but finally decided to review it. Served in a bottle.  A: beer was amber in color with a decent head.  S: The beer is very floral ( due to the nobel hops). There was a slight toasted malt taste  T: Smooth with a good balance between hops and malt.  O: This is a good beer. It lives up to the hype behold the success of the Boston Beer Co brand.

An orange/copper coloured lager with a white head. Good retention and very carbonated. Slightly hazy.  Smell is a bit grainy, some caramel and some America hops, Cascade I assume and some more herbal hop.  This is a nice lager, it has that standard lager taste, some grain some hops but with a little extra. A little darker malts and that typical American hop profile although I believe they also used some German/Czech hop as well.  Overall a very nice lager, downside is that it is quite rare and expensive.  Reviewed with the style in mind ofcourse, hench the high marks.

Served from 12oz brown bottle into a pint glass. Freshness date April.  A: Golden in color, slightly darker and richer hue than corn beers (not saying this is a corn beer, simply comparing colors). A finger of snow white head, fair retention, not a lot of lacing. Can see some active carbonation bubbles continuously floating up. Looks very clear, nice filtration, very clean.  S: Nose is malty, sweet, roasted caramel earthy malts and floral grassy hops. Slightly light on the aromatic scale, though certainly not unscented. You'll want to swirl this a bit to breathe it before getting the full whiff.  T: Immediately hits me with some decent IBUs, I'm getting rinds of grapefruit or orange, along with floral hops, some grass, and then on the mid palate it calms nicely as the roasty toasty malts come in to put the bitterness in check. Finishes dry with with a pleasant sweetness but not overly sweet. It's classy, it's not complex or thoroughly layered, but it has a nice balance and elegance. It's simplicity works in it's favor.  M: The mouthfeel is perhaps the most disappointing aspect of this beer. It's on the lighter side of medium bodied, right there on the border between medium and a little watery. Carbonation is a lot more moderate than what you'd think after seeing the active carbonation bubbles, it's not bad, but I wouldn't complain if they had upped it a tad. It also isn't leaving much of what I like to call a "savor coating".  D: Highly drinkable, very pleasant all-around, goes down smooth as silk, could have 6 or more in a session without much to complain about.  O: Overall, this is a great beer. It should have got an overall 4.0, but I docked half a point for the cost. It's on the expensive side, and for the price, I can think of better craft beers that are $2 or more cheaper for a case (there are also worse beers than this that cost more, so it's not that bad). I'd buy it again if it was on the shelf when none of those were available, but it wouldn't be my first pick among an assortment of craft.  I'm enjoying it though, very much so, and I'd recommend giving it a shot if you've never done so. It's at least worth a one-time experience.

Bottle into tall pilsner A – A clear golden amber brew gave a good sized nearly white head with decent retention and lacing before subsiding to a lumpy pillow 4 S – Much more floral than my memory serves, mild sweetness and grassiness with a bit of toasted malts 4 T – A light toasted grains/malt sweetness with a fading herbal bitterness towards the finish, good balance 3.5 M – Very middle of the road, a light body & wet, a bit flat 3.5 O – When you step into Bob’s Country Bunker and are looking at the full BMC line-up with a Boston Lager trailing on the end… we’ll both select this beer. Very drinkable, but most other craft exceeds this brew. 3.5

Appearance: Bold amber. playful amount of bubbles. Certainly pours darker than the average lager.  Smell: A little hoppy. Some citrus in there. A little bit of hop smell as well.  Taste: Light but has some citrus notes. The hops work really well in this beer. They're there but certainly keeps the lightness of a lager.  Mouthfeel: Quite nice. Sits will with only a little too much carbonation. A slight lingering harsh bitterness but not too bad.  Overall: The best lager I've ever had for sure. Smooth with slightly more hops than other lagers I've had. Great as a standalone beer or as an everyday beer. For being so attainable this is a wonderful beer. The flavors play into each other very well.

A - Pours a very clear amber brown with a thick two finger off-white head with sticky lacing and decent retention.  S - Herbal notes, with a hops spiciness and finishes with some nice malts.  T - Light and refreshing taste good balance of bitter hops and malty bread. I can't believe this is the first time I've had Boston Lager from Samuel adams.  M - Light bodied with a good touch of carbonation.

Poured from 12oz brown bottle to Sam Adams Perfect Pint Glass.  A - The beer is an amber gold color and perfectly clear with a creamy off-white bubbly head. Decent retention and lacing.  S - An earthy hop tone with a lot of caramel malt flavor.  T - Similar to the nose the beer starts with the earthy hop flavor. The middle of the beer brings out the malt character: caramel, toast, and biscuit flavors. The beer finishes crisp and clean and a little floral, dry.  M - Light bodied with good carbonation.  D - Very easy to drink.  Overall, this is a pretty solid beer. I would have no qualms about drinking more.  Note: This review was a re-post from my former account, jmkratt, which was hacked and I lost all my reviews...sorry for the redundancy.  Serving type: bottle

Pours a medium brown color with a thin head into my snifter. Minimal lacing on the side of the glass. Very clear in appearance. The nose is yeast, malt, and slight hops. Very crisp smelling brew... nothing noteworthy or offensive here. The taste follows suit. This is a very sessionable brew. One that you could put several down and not notice the abv. Feel is lightly carbonated, clean and crisp. Overall, a good beer for the style. Cheers.

Best by: April 2012; Poured in a pint glass.  A - One inch white creamy, fluffy head with nice retention; Dark gold/straw color; clear appearance with visible carbonation; Nice lacing left all down the glass  S - Biscuity and fresh bready malts with a touch of lemon; Hops provide a nice balance with spicy and floral characteristics  T - Very similar to the nose; Biscuity and fresh baked bread flavors and subtle lemon zest; The presence of noble hops are here for sure: a little spicy, but mostly very grassy  M - Light to medium bodied; Good amount of carbonation; Pretty crisp finish with a bit of lingering grassy hops  O - This is a very solid lager that I have enjoyed numerous times. It's very well balanced with the biscuity/bready and noble hop flavors. It's also super drinkable and has a taste that is truly unmatched. I can see why Sam Adams includes this flagship beer in many of their variety packs as it's a great beer to enjoy with good company.

Appearance: Orange gold. Great fluffy snow white head that endures for five minutes or so with nice structure. Spotty lacing.  Smell: Yeasty, malty, mild hoppy  Taste: Mild sweetness, Mild bitterness, hint of something approaching metallic, hint of something bordering on the nicer side of wet cardboard.  Mouthfeel: Slightly round. A faint tingle on the tongue tip.  Overall: Decent beer for when you want a beer and aren't too fussed with what sort and aren't looking to think about it or remember it. If average is defined by the range of craft beers (it is for me) this is average. If average is macro territory, this is a bit above average. It's not a beer I look for or crave, but rather is one I'll accept and be thankful for when the other options are macros.

Appearance - Pours a light, deep amber. Finger width head that dissipates into a thin but consistent lacing.  Smell - Faint caramel. hints of spice. The lack of a strong aroma is fairly consistent with most SA beers.  Taste - Caramel to start, a touch then follows through to a dry, slightly spicy, slightly grassy bitter-hop finish. Slight metallic twang in the aftertaste.  Mouthfeel - Light. Carbonation is a tad on the low side, but it works with this lager.  Overall - A solid beer from Sam Adams that appeals to a wide array of beer drinkers. It's their most popular beer but not their best, IMO. Over the years, I've found I can get through 3 or 4 of these puppies before looking to bring a reliever into the game. Drinks closer to a red than your standard lager.

poured from a 12oz bottle into a standard pint glass. best enjoyed by May 2012  a: light copper color with a thick and fluffy white head that sticks to the glass for a long time.  s: malt-forward aroma with noticeable floral and citrus hops.  t: toasted malts hit first quickly followed by a pleasant bitter floral hop flavor. perfectly balanced and delicious.  m: great mouthfeel.  underrated around these parts, but it deserves the all the praise it has received. recommended.

Poured from bottle into pint glass  Appearance - A nice deep golden color that forms a very nice white head that fades to give some decent lacing. While drinking the foam clings to the side of the glass. Quite nice for the style.  Smell - Mainly malty smells with a very slight amount of toasty sugar and caramel smell quickly following. Some nice hop of aroma then comes in toward the end with mainly citrus but a small amount of floral as well.  Taste - Malty breadiness first meets the tongue followed quickly by a caramel like sweetness. A bit of hoppiness then comes in but seems to be subdued again my the malty-caramel sweetness that was first present.  Mouthfeel - For the style this is nearly spot on. It is smooth and perfectly carbonated. Not to thick not too thin and very, very drinkable.  Overall - Who is to say that the flagship beers of large commercial breweries can't be good is really mistaken. Sam Adam's Boston lager is Fantastic!!

You know, I hadn't really had this beer for years, and to be honest it's probably better then I remember. Sam Adams is interesting to me... some of their beers I find barely drinkable, and others like their flagship beer I think are just solid and decent all around. That being said, I think this beer in terms of appearance, smell, taste, and mouthfeel is a beer that was responsible for bringing people over to the craft beer side, and I can see why. It's got some hops, but it's not overly aggressive. It has some slight sweetness in the taste. It's well balanced. It is certainly more full then the common American Adjust Lager. Definitely enjoyable and easy to drink.

Poured from a bottle into a glass... again as I said in a previous review of the Sam Adams "Octoberfest", the Samuel Adams brand isn't a favorite of mine.. So don't expect a glaring review. Much less a well educated one.  The Appearance is a good clover honey color.. with no taste of clover of course. My head didn't last long and dissipated pretty quickly.. (pretty par for the course in all honesty)  This lager smelled like an amber colored beer. I didn't get a wiff of any fruits or anything that would stand out and call notice. I should have smelled something shouldn't I? For that reason I'm going below average - I may have went too far but again, Sam Adams isn't a favorite.  Taste - I probably need to see what the date was on this variety pack, as the taste - well it taste like every other Samuel Adams Boston Lager I've ever had. Decent... not so hoppy, but yet way more flavor than my normal beers of choice.  Samuel Adams if anything for me has the "mouthfeel" down pat. All the beers of their's that I've had have a good solid crispness to them. I like that. It's what to me makes a cold beer refreshing... I've never jogged a mile and wanted a Guiness (sp) afterwards, but a cold crisp beer yes! I have wanted that.  Overall to me, it's average, it appears it wants to be something better than Budwieser - which I guess it is.. but the characteristics of it do not really distinguish it as something I'd brag about. That's me... and my $0.02

Pint at Sir John A in Ottawa. From notes.  A - Poured into a Perfect Pint glass. Medium copper colour with a nice two finger creamy eggshell head. Bright. The head is nice and fluffy and leaves great retention with a full finger and great rings of lace. Good carbonation visible too.  S - Gentle grassy hops with an obvious cascade style grapefruit note and biscuity notes.  T - More cascade grapefruit character and biscuity malts, a little grassy with a noble hop kick too.  M - Gentle carbonation, light to medium body, nice bitterness in the finish.  O/D - A solid lager. Clearly a classic with a great hop character and balance. Very drinkable.

12 oz bottle, with best by date of March 2012  appears a clear bright copper color, with 1/2" of bright white colored head. good retention. aroma of pale malt and grassy hops.  taste is just a little caramel sweetness, with a crisp hop finish. lighter in body, high carbonation typical for the style.  it's a good "starter" craft beer - and often the best beer available at chain restaurants. but nothing special.

Poured from a pint glass from a 12 ozer and the beer is a nice clear amber color with a 1 finger off white head that doesn't hang around long, nor have any lacing to speak of.  Malty with some slight hops in the nose.  A bit of residiual sweetness, nicely carbed, just a shade over medium on the mouthfeel.  Lacking only a bit more crispness to be spot on style wise this is a very nice Vienna Lager in my opinion (along the same line as Dos Equis Amber which I like alot for an any day brew with about any food). This is a solid A Vienna to me.

Rich and aromatic flavors in a light-bodied beer. Maltiness gives it a pretty big mouthfeel along with plenty of carbonation in the usual Sam Adams style. A sharp touch to go with the mellow caramel flavors. Hops are distinct but more flowery than bitter.  I wonder how many people widened their beer horizons with a sip of Sam Adams? Who could resist-- it's not very bitter, but it does provide a painless education in hoppiness. A distinctive and reliable beer. I've found it in the driest beer deserts as well as the cheesiest Mexican joints. I think Boston Brewing does us all a service by making so this flavorful beer so popular and widely available.

Poured from a bottle into a pint glass.  A: Pours a light amber/ copper color with a decent head and good lacing.  S: Hops, caramel, and grains.  T: Starts off with a spicy hop twang followed by caramel malts and toasty grains, cracker and biscuit like. The hops reassert themselves a bit towards the end along with the malt.  M: Light body with decent carbonation and a little dry in the finish. Crisp.  Overall: A very enjoyable lager. Nice flavors, well balanced and drinkable. A very good gateway beer.

Poured into a snifter.  Appearance: Clear; light amber in color. Not much head. Some lacing.  Smell: I pick up mainly malts; very clean overall.  Taste: Malts come through with a smooth lager taste. Light hops back it up. Semi-dry finish.  Mouthfeel: Light; low carbonation.  Overall: A very sessionable lager, just not much there. Still, a step up from the regular BMC selections. A great stepping stone to more flavorful Sam Adams offerings.

Bottle poured into pint.  A: Clear amber with a two finger white head that develops into rocky white islands. Good lacing.  S: Lots of caramel and a tinge of hops.  T: This is a really malt-forward beer with a lot of caramel and toffee upfront. The noble hops come in about halfway through and aren't too assertive. Aftertaste is bitter and hoppy, but again, not too bad.  M: Creamy, medium-bodied, with the carbonation maybe helping out to balance the hops at the end.  O: This one is an American classic. Well-rounded, balanced, and sessionable. For most BMC drinkers that turn into craft beer drinkers, this is one of the gateways. Cheers!

Served out of a bottle. Upon opening some smoke came out. It has a white one finger head that laces pretty excessively. The body is a lighter brownish color that almost reminds me of an adjunct lager but is a bit darker than that. Bubbles also rise to the top.  The smell is of hops, and caramel malt.  The taste is very very hoppy with a hint of caramel malt. The aftertaste is very hoppy also. This for me is very pleasing as I enjoy this combination.  The mouthfeel is pretty good and the beer is carbonated.  Overall its a nice hoppy beer. Very enjoyable. give this one a try.

A - Very nice, clear copperish pour with a one finger white head. Head shrunk down quickly however and the lacing was dismal in the standard pint glass. EDIT: Lacing far better second time around.  S - Lightly toasted maltiness, some bready scent, bit of caramel, and some hop aroma.  T - Pleasantly sweet in the front from the caramel malt. Bready in nature as well before giving way to a complimentary spicy profile from the hops and a moderate bitterness to balance.  MF - Lighter side of medium bodied, but bigger than its ABV suggests. Drinkable and light enough to session but without sacrificing taste. Perfect carbonation, nice finish.  O - The one that introduced me to better beers. Tasty, balanced, affordable. Great feel, sessionable. Works throughout the year. A staple for a reason.

Poured into a pint glass. Pours a light amber color with a finger of creamy white head. A bit of lace on the rim.  A little bit of grassy hops and a little bit of fruitiness in the background. The flavor is full of grassy hops with some notes of caramel with some rich malts here.  The body is light with good carbonation. Overall this one is really a staple. I've had hundreds of times and I'll have it again. It's never m first choice, but it never seems to be a bad one.

Poured from a 12 oz bottle into a pint glass. Served at fridge temp.  Reddish-Gold with a 1 finger cream colored head. Actively carbonated, perfunctory lacing.  Aroma: Highly fragrant Noble Hoppiness.  Mouthfeel: decent medium.  Taste: Distinctly bitter, this is a well hopped lager with a kiss of toasted caramel malt.  Notes: Refreshing, thirst quenching and at 4.9% abv a highly sessionable beer. Priced nicely and ubiquitous this should be an icon of American Beer.

A: Pours a clear golden amber with a compact white head. Little streams of carbonation are very noticeable once the beer settles in the glass.  S: The nose is dominated by herbal, grassy hops, though caramel is present in the background.  T: Very nicely balanced with notes of lemon, caramel, biscuits, grass, herbs, lime, minerals, and straw on the palate. The finish is hoppy and cleansing with spicy, grassy hops asserting themselves.  M: Medium bodied and dry with firm carbonation.  O: This is a really nice Vienna lager that is not nearly as heavy as some interpretations of the style. Though this may not be the most exciting craft brew out there, it has stood the test of time and is deserving of its reputation as an American classic. If you haven't tried this beer, ignore the detractors and give it a fair shot.

A: Pours into my Perfect Pint glass very light brown, clear almost yellow. A small white head rises and falls, leaving decent lacing. A ton of bubbles race from the bottom of the glass.  S: Caramel malts with a floral hop background.  T: Malt forward, caramel, with the slight hoppiness from the smell. The hops are not like that of an IPA, moreso they balance out the malty lager taste to keep the palate interested.  MF: Light, carbonated well, if not too much so. Extremely drinkable, and a go to at bars with sub-par offerings.  O: Can't knock this. Great for the price, and an above average "gateway beer." Honestly am glad beers like this are starting to dominate the larger beer markets.

How can one call oneself a beer reviewer without reviewing the father of American microbrews, Sam Adams? Without further ado:  Poured from a bottle into a pilsner glass.  A - A clear golden-amber color with a small perfectly white head, that retained at least a thin layer for a very long time. Good lacing.  S - Spicy, earthy, herbal hops. Not much else, but a nice aroma. A tiny bit of malt aroma comes out as it warms.  T - Nicely balanced, with spicy hops dominating the flavor profile. Slightly fruity and floral at the same time, but not so much that you could really identify a specific fruit flavor. At no time could you describe it as "malty", but you'd notice if it wasn't there.  M - Tingly carbonation and a medium body. Finishes crisp and clean.  O - A solid B-level craft beer that's available at nearly any bar or corner store. I cant count the number of times I have been at a restaurant and been saved from drinking BMC products by this beer. If I'm in a hurry to get to a party or function where there is a need to bring beer and I only have time for a stop at a convenience store, this is still a solid choice. Drank a million of them over the years and probably have many more ahead of me.

pours a light amber brown into a copper body with orange tint. 1/4" head that dissipates quickly. a nice frothy, molten lacing that lingers a while. slightest presence of sediment and bubbles.  smells mighty wheaty and mighty hoppy, not just any hops though. sweet, aromatic hops. and plenty of them, as any 'sam adams' commercial will surely tell you.  tastes of strong floral hops, that's it. all it needs to be. but not ipa hoppy, though. not kick start my heart shit, just enough to be jumpy.  lighty sweet, almost stout hoppy on-bringing. crisp, wet aftertaste.  word hop and it's derivatives used six times in this review, you don't say.  **Enjoy before month notched: Feb 2012

A - Pours an amber/copper color with a nice white head an good lacing.  S - Very malty, some caramel notes. There is also faint hints of fruits and spices. Also, some light hops are present.  T - Mild hops mixed with the malt flavors to create the classic flavor we all know. It's not complex, but it's solid and enjoyable.  M - Medium bodied, fantastic carbonation with a chewy feel to it that lingers. Nice aftertaste of malted flavors and very sessionable.  O - Samuel Adams Boston Lager is a classic. I have a long history with this beer (it was my first legal beer and first craft beer) and it's always worth a revisit. It's not the most exciting or complex beer, but an old friend and a great standby whenever you're at a bar with limited craft options.

Poured from bottle into official sam adams pint glass. I, like many of you, have had this a million times....tap and botle. I have even been to the brewery in south boston. Its a great beer. Done. For me, sam adams is one of the few breweries that you can bring a 12 pack to a bbq and please the ba beer drinker but also please the massess. You dont need a review for this...its sam adams lager!

clear copper color. nice steady steam of bubbles. big white moussey head.  nice subtle malty aroma. spcey hop aroma, saaz? caramel. nicely balanced bouquet, just tres petite.  malty sweet upfront. hoppy finish. floral hop flavor in the middle balance with that caramel malt. a modest, but in no way timid palate.  medium/light body. crisp clean distinctly lager finish.  not bad. quite sessionable in fact. though it has in no way converted me from my preference for ales.

Jersey. Served in a Boston Lager perfect pint.  A - Medium orange with a foamy cream colored head. Great retention and tons of lacing.  S - Spicy, fruity, very malty.  T - similar to the smell but the spices really pop at the finish.  D - Medium body and average carbonation.  O - One I just never order. Glad to finally try it.

On tap following the Sam Adams brewery tour.  Translucent orange-gold, solid white head, fantastic lace and retention. Hoppy, citrus, caramel-y aroma. Similar flavors in the taste: starts citrus-y, nice malt backbone, finishes clean and bitter. Light body, wish it were bigger and more creamy.  I keep forgetting this is a lager -- an impressive lager brew.

This is my go-to "table beer". Very well done, very consistent, a complex European flavor to the lager, with a nice balance of flavors with no off tastes.  It was at a micro-brew beer fest when I realized just how much I liked this beer. After trying 20 to 40 other beers, I found this to have the most refined flavor.  Not sure why, but I've found the bottle beer to be often better than the tap beer. This is the only beer I've found this to be the case (prefer bottle over tap). Often find some off flavors with the Sams Lager on tap.

#3 in the "sure, why not?" file, and #3 in the Sam Adams winter pack. Poured into a Kostritzer pilsener glass. (Seriously, why haven't I reviewed this yet?!)  A: Pours a dark amber/copper color with a one-finger soapy off-white head that doesn't have great retention. But it leaves quite a bit of soapy lacing on the edges of the glass. Carbonation bubbles are present if you look hard enough.  S: Main aroma is those earthy, dank Hallertau hops. I can also smell some of the amber malts if I really concentrate. Nothing earth-shattering.  T: Opens up with a toasty malt flavor, and ends with some grassy hops. Not the most complex or bold beer on the market by any stretch, but super easy to drink, and sufficiently satisfying on the palate.  M: Like you'd expect from a good lager; smooth, medium-light body, incredibly easy going down, and prickly carbonation that isn't overdone. The bubbles can catch up to you if you're not careful.  O: One of the best go to beers around. Sure, I'd pick a lot of other beers before this one, but consider this...I can walk a couple hundred feet to the local dive bar and pick up one of these for about a buck fifty. I can find it just about any place that serves liquor, and many times, this is the only other option apart from BMC, Corona, and *MAYBE* Heineken. While it's just 'good' overall, its versatile nature and superb sessionability make it ideal for luring BMC drinkers into the world of craft.

Poured into a pint glass  This is the beer that made Boston famous. It is truly worthy of that claim.  Appearance: Copper yellow, clear. Two finger head  S: Hops and spices  Taste: Malty with spices from the various hops  Mouthfeel: Watery  This is a session beer, that will wind up in my fridge again.

Good ole reliable, probably had more of these than any other non BMC brew, bout time I review it.  A: A clear clean copper, rather thin head, but it hangs around, and leaves some significant webs.  S: Not too strong but malt base with some citrus/sweet hop scent.  T: Bread crust with a hint of toffee, then a kiss of hops to clense the palate, incredibly balanced.  M: Great carbonation, a bit chewy, based on flavor heaviness really sessionable, but you'll have to burp once or twice.  O: Probably the most versitle beers ever, great for any season, any occasion, very sessionable, great balance, theres a reason its the real king of beers.

Extremely clear, light amber color. Decent head and lacing.  Crisp malty aroma. Slightly sweet.  A great balance of malt and hops. Relatively complex with a clean, slightly bitter finish  Medium bodied mouthfeel carries this beer well. Adequate carbonation.  This is a great "anytime" beer. Really good, but not over the top in any way.

This is one of those beers that I seems to come full circle on my beer journey.  It pours a very clear copper with nice white head.  The smell is somewhat laid back but with malt and an earthy spice coming through.  The taste is extremely malty on the front and mid. Very bready with a lingering bitterness on the back.  Simple and amazing beer. I'm surprised I have not reviewed this before.

Had this on draft with dinner at a restaurant. Poured 22oz. into a 'texas' sized glass.  A- Dark copper, amber in color. Clear with this head to it. Left small amounts of lace on glass.  S- Sweet smelling, caramel malts mostly. Floral hop aroma towards the end of it.  T- Sweeter taste but good balance. Floral hops come through most. Maybe some citrus hop flavor as well. Bitterness is fairly mild as hops are cut into by sweet malts. Good balance and enjoyable.  M- Lighter body, moderate carbonation to it.  O- Not to shabby. Enjoyed 2 glasses of it. Doubt I would pick it over some other local craft, but out at a restaurant wouldn't mind another glass.

Appearance: Light copper and amber with golden hues. Good amount of white head that sticks around and to the side of the glass all the way down.  Smell: Very aromatic smells delicious, with both carmel malt and floral hops with spice note coming through, nice...  Taste: Sweet malt and caramel, with hop good flavour. Just enough bitterness that has a spice bite to it. Some sweetness to the finish but finishes dry with a good hop presence...  Overall: A very well crafted beer! Just enou hops but very well balanced. This has been popular for a long time for good reason, its a solid, well crafter brew!

Two fingers of creamy head that forms larger bubbles and dissipates. Hazy gold-amber color. Decent lace.  Classic lager nose. Some grassy/floral hops and light malt.  Taste is a sort of fizzier lager. More malt than in an adjunct (duh). Pretty easy drinking, crisp but not bitter, malty but not heavy. Good balance.  Mouthfeel is pretty smooth, well textured. Not great, but not bad.  If this were the sort of beer I liked, I could see how this might become a go-to. Widely available, brewed by a macro brewer who still has significant roots in the craft scene. Hard to be outstanding in the style, but this is not bad, not bad at all.

Serving type - Bottle  Appearance - Light golden tan/ brown, much like a american lager, 1/2 creamy head, some lacing.  Smell - Hops, some malts, kinda floral/grassy with some yeast aroma.  Taste - Had this many many times, first time sitting down to review. Lots of bitter crisp hops with a nice background. This must be a fresh bottle cause i dont remember this being quite this hoppy. The yeast adds that grassy flavor, and works well with the bold malts. Theres a little spice at the finish, but no alcohol flavor really.  Mouthfeel - Light and crisp, with a tounge bitterness from the hops. Malts help coat the bitter hops and balance this beer out. Aftertaste is light and not long lasting hop bitterness.  Overall - Very nice and easy drinker. Hoppy and malty, moreso then most lagers ive had. A great starter or evening sipper, or a great option if your at a bar and all they have is nasty macro beers on tap.

I've had this many times and each time I have it I ask myself why I don't have it more often. L: amber with a nice head and nice lacing S: this is my standard rating as I don't seem to detect aromas as well as most of you T: Years ago when I first tried it I thought it was too bitter but now I love the nice bitterness it brings to the glass. A nice maltiness as well. F: Very good for a 5.0 ABV lager O: I prefer to get this in a can. I'm not sure why but it just tastes better to me when it is canned. Some have argued that it really isn't a Vienna lager. That may be because I'm not a fan of most of the Vienna lagers I try.

A great beer from the largest American brewer that brews its own...  Pours with a full head that sticks around a while.  Smell and taste of hops and slightly tea-ish with a hint of herb.  Mouth feel is nice and smooth. Not too hard or creamy.  Could hold it own against many imports.  Nice.

Great copper orange color that develops a good head of thick bubbles when poured in the center of a pint glass. Yeasty maltiness and some good hop scents jump from the glass. Good refreshing carbonation. This one is a great standby and will always satisfy. This is about the only lager that I enjoy. Good example of the Samuel Adams lineup.

Bottle from a winter mixer poured into a Perfect Pint Glass. Has a Best By date of March 2012.  Very pretty copper color with a thing white head. Thin layer sticks around the middle of the surface because of the laser etching. The bubbles rising up from the bottom are enthralling.  Started right out of the fridge with a distinct "beer" smell that reminded me of college - that isnt meant as a compliment, but it isnt a total dig either; it was a memory inducing smell. Sweet malty smell shows up as it warms a bit, nothing too strong. European grassy hops are evident and not overwhelming.  Tastes are not terribly different from the smell. Tasty sweet malted barley, European hops.  It has a nice smooth texture, but at the same time has good carbonation.  I love Sam Adams, even if I dont drink it as often as I used to. It reminds me of why I love beer, and particularly why I love BETTER beer.  Cheers.

Ah Boston Lager, this beer has saved me in more dive bars than I can count. Not the greatest, but not bad in a pinch... be it at a dive bar, bbq, or baseball game.  Pours a bright orange copper color, perfect clarity and saturated tone. Creamy, fluffy head of foam at first that dwindles after 10 minutes or so. Plenty of lace in the glass, and a thin skim eventually.  Smells slightly sweet, toasty and biscuity. Vague fruity apple and pear notes slide in too.  Flavors are similar, some bready malt sweetness, fruity yeast. Feels a bit more full bodied than many lagers. Lingering toastiness with a slight floral hop note. Little to no hop bitterness present. Easy to have a couple with food. A pretty versatile, above average lager.

Pours an amber color with a one finger head that sticks around with decent lacing. Aroma of caramel malts with a decent hop aroma. Taste follows the nose great balance between sweetness and bitterness. Crisp and clean, this is a refreshing, highly drinkable brew. It's nothing mind blowing but it's a good all around beer

poured into a Imperial measured and marked pint tulip glass nice looking amber body underneath a really frothy head that didn't last as long as some.  Light malt notes on the nose with a little fruity hint and well hidden hop notes from the first beer I've put in the fridge in yay long.  Ice cold beer? what a stranger. A nice kick of hoppy tastes and not much else making an okay beer.  I'm not a lager fan but I had to know about this American 'Classic'  worth the try, far better than any other big name beers stateside.

I've had this beer a lot but never really sat down to give it a fair review. Poured from 12oz bottle dated best by February 2012 into a Samuel Adams pint glass:  A: Pours a light, burnished orange color with a translucent and effervescent body. Boasts a thick, half inch head that sticks around a while with an eggshell hue. Looks very refreshing and Boston Beer Company did a great job making the Perfect Pint feel like it was the handcrafted delivery vessel for the brew.  S: Subtle grassy notes up front, very crisp aromas easily lead you to the delicately refreshing profile underneath. Refined and inviting.  T: Light touches of grassy hops are the first thing to wash over the palate, brushing gentle strokes of flavors that marry the hops and slightly sweet malts with well executed balance. Finishes very clean with a light, sweet malt touch.  M: Great smooth consistency. Medium bodied with lively carbonation and very easy on the palate. Crisp and refreshing.  O: Always a faithful standby, there is a reason the Samuel Adams Boston lager is the flagship brew of Boston Beer Company. Widely available and infinitely drinkable, you can't go wrong with this beer wherever you are. Delicacy and attention to detail are king for this style this beer; Boston Beer Company has done a great job!

Appearance: Its a sexy beer. Its an light orange/copper color with an off-white head. It is extremely clear.  Smell: I smell citrus,lemon in particular  Taste: Complex malty taste that finishes with a delightful hoppy character. Greatly improves in taste as it warms in the glass.  Mouthfeel: Medium-light body that is best at 'cool' temperatures  Overall: Its a good brew, enjoy

Poured from a 12 oz. bottle into a standard pint glass.  Appearance: Pours a nice light-copper/amber color with a two-finger head that quickly dissipates. Moderate lacing is left as I drink.  Smell: Citrus, malty, hoppy, spicy, good. I can tell I'll enjoy this.  Taste: Mmmmm. Sweet malts and spicy hops with citrus-ness mixed in. Light bitterness at finish.  Mouthfeel: Fairly heavy carbonation with a light body, I could seriously drink this all day. It's very refreshing. Slight dry finish.  Overall: Man I love this stuff; whether it's winter, spring, summer, or fall, this beer is appropriate for all times. Easy to drink and easy to enjoy, great taste and an awesome beer.

Poured from their winter sampler into my 12oz beer glass...  Appearance - Poured a quick finger of tight white head, color is a transparent lite amber.  Smell - Wheat bread, carmel, touch of vanilla, slight minerals.  Taste - Simple and flavorful, this is a very balanced mix of fresh wheat bread, nice semi-sweet malt backbone, and lite meadowy hops. Finishes with slightly dry breadcrust and crisp minerals.  Mouthfeel - Lite mouthfeel, medium carb adds a nice fresh crispiness, finishes slightly dry.  Overall - A very good, flavorful and refreshing beer. Very well balanced and extremely sessionable.

It's a clear amber color with a head so thick you can float a bottlecap on it. But that head quickly turns into lace.  It smells biscuity/bready with a hint of hops.  It's very malty and sort of sweet on the front of the tongue. It leaves a lingering hop flavor.  It's crisp and medium bodied.  Overall, this beer's all right with me. It's pretty session worthy and a good price.

A: golden to light amber with a one inch head and slight lacing and ring around the sides for the remainder of the glass.  S: smells of bittering hops mostly, also some pale malt  T: tastes mostly of the malt, full flavored. It also has that nice hop bitterness, and the aftertaste is beautiful. Full of malt.  M: medium body with a smooth start, crisp finish, and sticky and malty leftover taste. Nice work.  O: delicious, available, can't believe I haven't tried this in years. Wonderful and cheap beer.

Poured from a 12oz bottle into a SA Perfect Pint glass.  A: Lively amber body with a creamy cap of white head.  S: The caramel malt profile is prominent and inviting, but there is an earthy hop presence that sets this apart from most Vienna Lagers.  T: Again with the hops; they bitter and sharpen this already tasty beer and provide for a full, bright drink and a dry, crisp finish.  D: Great drinkability. Really, beers like this are the drinkability yardstick that I hold to other beers.  Overall: An American classic, and it earned it. Boston Lager, along with SNPA and a couple of other brews is, and always will be one of the quintessential "entry-level" and "old favorite" craft beers of me and many other drinkers. It remains balanced, tasty, easy-drinking, but subtly complex.

I've had this many times but I've only reviewed it on tap. Poured from a 12 oz bottle into a pint glass best before Dec date. This pours a nice amber color with nice foamy white held with good retention. The smells are of crisp floral hops and malts. The feel is medium. The taste is pretty good, crisp floral hops and a nice malts backbone. This was always one of my early go to beers, and its still good these days even if I don't get it as often.

12 ounce bottle poured into a Sam Adams "Perfect Pint" glass.  A: Copper / amber colored body, completely clear with a fluffy thick two finger head. Dissipation wasn't as rapidly as expected, and left really nice sticky patches of lacing on the walls. A thin white retention ring coated the surface the entire time.  S: Floral and somewhat piney faint hop notes with rich, sweet caramel malts. Dry breads and husk towards the back end of the nose. Not a bad smelling beer by any means; nothing is off though perhaps it's about as aromatic as a lager could be?  T: Sweet caramel malts and pumpernickel bread is up front. Extremely minor hops do come through, a bit sappy and floral. Not really bitter at all, very smooth and balanced. This is a very approachable and easy flavor profile that I'd give to some "new craft drinkers" to try.  M: Active bubbly carbonation, loads of bubbles give a fizzy but somewhat creamy feel to the beer. Talk about an incredibly drinkable beer, this goes down entirely too easy and smoothly. Crisp, medium-bodied, damn good for the style.  I will gladly take a Boston Lager when I'm out at a bar or restaurant. It wouldn't necessarily be my first choice given other craft options; however I love that this beer is so widely available for a solid fallback. A very nice, smooth and easy drinking craft lager.

I picked this up to knock off the Vienna Lager style for BA.  I poured this into a pint glass to savor the stronger lager flavors. On the pour I got only one finger of foam. There was quite a bit of little bubbles in this beer  Off the top I get a decent amount of grassy funk. This was much stronger than the typical lager.  The flavor is much stronger. I like the taste, and I don't typically enjoy lagers. There is a lot of grass, funk, and some bitterness.  I recommend this as a gateway beer for people drinking adjunct lagers that want to move on to something much, much better.

Took me a while to actually write down my thoughts on this standard of American mainstream craft beer. Pours a deep golden 3/4 inch head into my chalice. Smell is inviting but not too overpowering. Malty but not too angry. The lacing urges me to take the beer and have my way with it. And I do. Nice firm malty backbone, slightly sassy, with a nice smack of hoppy bitterness. Not trying to prove anything with its medium body this lager has got what it takes to keep my attention. Definitely sessionable and overall my go to beer when the establishment I frequent cannot provide an exotic beer.

Draft  Appearance - Copper colour with an average size frothy off-white coloured head. There is a low amount of carbonation showing and there is some decent lacing on the sides of the glass. The head lasted for 5 minutes before it began to dissipate.  Smell - Malts, caramel, hops  Taste & Mouth - There is an average amount of carbonation and most of the taste is made up of caramel and malts mixed with light hops. There is also a very faint citrus taste going on. It ends with a caramel/brown sugar malty aftertaste.  Overall - Definitely one of the better options for draft beer at most restaurants in my area. I can see how this would work well as a gateway beer to get people away from drinking basic boring macros.

A: This beer pours a nice golden color with a half inch thick head.  S: I get a little hope scent and some malt. Not much else.  T: This beer has a nice amount of hops for a lager and has a nice malty sweetness.  M: The beer is one of the easiest drinkable beers out there. It has a perfect amount of carbonation and crispness.  O: One of the best lagers on the market. I am not a huge lager fan, but it tastes good and it easy to drink.

Poured into 13 oz tulip. Pours a nice bright amber, with a nice one inch head, some lacing. Smell is bready, some citrus, and pine. Taste is that with a hint of carmel, very easy to drink. This is the beer that 17 years ago changed me. All I wanted to do is find that same reaction to another beer, that I had to my first Sammy. Then I found BA a year and half ago and have been amazed so many times since. Still a nice beer.

Poured from a bottle of a 12 pk running at $15.99 to a tulip glass, best by Jan 2012 date notched on it.  Appearance: Pours a nice amber copper color, 2 inch thick frothy head with excellent retention  Smell: Plenty of hops, piney floral smell.  Taste: Very crisp and refreshing spot on mouth feel, you taste the hops more then anything else the piney notes the floral and the bitterness, not as bitter tho it goes down smooth a great beer with a body to it leaves you wanting for more.  Overall: I'm not a lager guy but this beer is outstanding compared to other lagers. A session beer goes great with bbq's something nice to share with friends one of the beers that people often transition to from drinking the macro beers, their available almost everywhere a nice beer and something you should try if you haven't.

12 Fluid Oz light brown bottle. Standard non-twist cap. Location Drank: Columbus, Ohio. Drink by 2/2010  Drank from bottle: A: Drank from bottle, no cloud whatsoever.  S: Floral, sweet and hops. No other smell detected.  T: Slight bitter taste upfront, then a nice malt flavor with slight yeast.  M: Medium to full beer. Medium carbonation. Crisp. Very nice balance between carbonation and fullness.  O: One of the best lagars I have had. I would try again, and would love to trey on draught.

Appearance- A very aggressive pour into a mug produces a roiling three finger off-white cap. It is very soapy and airy in nature. The retention is okay. It leaves a good Spackle of lace behind. The body is a really pale golden-amber with steady streams of carbonation.  Smell- There is a good amount of floral and herbal hoppiness to the nose. There's even a sweet malt character to it, very biscuit in nature.  Taste- Balance. I think that is the perfect word for this beer. Even served really cold, the sweet malt profile mixes with the floral hops and hop oil taste. It is hard to say which one comes first, but the hop bitterness is most pronounced in the finish and even comes off as a little spicy. What makes this beer really enjoyable is the biscuit malt backbone. That is a nice taste.  MF- This one is medium bodied and finishes relatively smooth. It is a good balance in the mouth feel department too. I am not sure you could do much more to have a great feel. Maybe a little more carbonation?  Overall- Honestly, I might agree with Jim Koch that this is the diaper dandy of the Samuel Adams line. It is a wonderful lager with great malt and hop balance. Why don't I get this more often?

Pours a clear medium amber. Big white head fades quickly. Nice floral German hop aroma, no citrus or pine. Light on carbonation, making the mouthfeel a bit bland. Very gentle on the palate. Easy to enjoy more than one in a sitting. Overall an above average selection. Iconic beer with wide appeal.

12oz bottle into tulip snifter. Best By: February 2012  Pours a clear dark golden with a decent, very light tan head.  The aroma is of light grassy, floral hops that blend nicely with toasty bread malts.  The taste is of toasty malts again, with grassy, floral hops. There is a light touch of lemon zest and spice.  A nice medium mouthfeel with fairly active carbonation.  Very easy drinking beer, it has some pleasant, subtle complexities.

I have reviewed lots of Boston Beers and so it's about time to do the flagship. I have always admired this brew as extremely drinkable. It has a bit more going for it than most of the style. It is a bit roastier, maltier and hoppier than the norm, and that's a good thing.  The near perfect balance goes down easy and the ber is very widely available. Always a good go to beer.

Poured out of a 12oz bottle into a pint glass.  Pours a deep gold with a solid one finger head that fades to a thin cover. Plenty of carbonation with this one.  Smell is of floral hops with some caramel.  The taste is much more pronounced than the smell with large amounts of hops of front that fades to a malty caramel before finishing with some hop bitterness. It is a very balanced beer.  Overall this is one of my go to beers and is especially great during warm weather. A perfect example of what a mass produced American lager should taste like.

Color: Golden honey color with lots of bubbles but hardly any head.  Smell: Mostly a bready malt.  Taste: Bitter up front with a yeasty aftertaste.  Mouth feel: Pretty average feel but way too much carbonation.  Overall: Nothing special here. The aftertaste lingers way too long. Not an enjoyable experience. Not as good as some of their other brews.

Appearance - A Beautiful dark golden beer with a fingers worth of snow white head that quickly disappears. Head sticks to the side of the glass very nicely, a very good looking beer.  Smell - Nothing too flashy here, just some bready malts that somehow allow for a nice smokiness and maybe a little lager yeast in the background  Taste - A little bitter bite up front followed my some caramel and toffee notes, probably from the malts. Lager yeast is the flavor that stays in my mouth while it gets washed down  Mouthfeel - Average, good carbonation  Overall - I haven't had one of these in years, in college i was quite fond of it, but now that my palate has changed this really isn't anything special. One of the better mass produced beers though obviously.
